author: Ursula K. Le Guin
description: A complex utopian/dystopian novel exploring anarchist and capitalist societies on a pair of contrasting planets, Anarres and Urras. It examines themes of freedom, societal structures, and the human condition.

title: On Truth
author: Harry Frankfurt
description: A philosophical essay exploring the concept of truth and its relation to sincerity and belief. Frankfurt argues that a person is sincere when they have the disposition to express what they believe, and that truth is a matter of correspondence between beliefs and reality.

title: A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man
author: James Joyce
description: A semi-autobiographical coming-of-age story following the intellectual and spiritual development of Stephen Dedalus, a young man growing up in Ireland. It explores themes of Irish identity, religion, and artistic expression.

title: Studies in Enlightenment
author: Nick Land
description: A collection of essays by Nick Land exploring themes of accelerationism, cybernetics, and the critique of modernity. It's a key text in post-structuralist and accelerationist thought.

title: The Second Sex
author: Simone de Beauvoir
description: A foundational text of second-wave feminism, *The Second Sex* is a comprehensive analysis of the historical and societal subjugation of women. Beauvoir examines the ways in which women have been defined as 'the Other' in patriarchal societies, exploring the myths, cultural norms, and economic factors that contribute to their oppression.

title: The Little Prince
author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
description: A pilot stranded in the desert meets a young prince fallen to Earth from a tiny asteroid. The prince recounts his travels to various planets and the strange adults he encountered, offering a poignant and philosophical exploration of life, love, and loss.
original_location_name: New York City, USA (original English translation)

title: Pictorial History of Philosophy
author: Unknown Author
description: A pictorial history of philosophy, covering the lives and ideas of prominent philosophers throughout history. It aims to make philosophical concepts accessible through illustrations and biographical accounts.

title: Linear Algebra and Differential Equations
author: Robert L. Devaney
description: This book provides a comprehensive introduction to linear algebra and differential equations, with a focus on applications and computational methods. It is designed for undergraduate students in mathematics, engineering, and the sciences.

title: The Complete Nonsense Book
author: Edward Lear
description: A collection of limericks, nonsense verse, and illustrations by Edward Lear, known for popularizing the limerick form. It is a classic of English children's literature and a source of whimsical and imaginative poetry.

title: The Communist Manifesto
author: Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels
description: A foundational text for communist thought, outlining the principles of class struggle and the inevitable overthrow of capitalism by the proletariat. It presents a historical analysis of class relations and a program for communist revolution.

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: David Hume
description: A seminal work of Scottish Enlightenment philosophy, *A Treatise of Human Nature* is a comprehensive attempt to apply the methods of empirical observation to the study of human psychology. It explores topics such as perception, reason, morality, and the self, and remains a foundational text in the fields of philosophy, psychology, and cognitive science.

title: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy: Applying Empirically Supported Techniques in Your Practice
author: William T. O'Donohue
description: This book provides a practical guide to implementing empirically supported cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) techniques in clinical practice. It covers a range of CBT approaches and their application to various psychological disorders.

title: 傾城之戀
author: 張愛玲
description: 傾城之戀 (Qing Cheng Zhi Lian), translated as 'Love in a Fallen City', is a novella by Eileen Chang. It's a poignant story of a love affair between a divorced woman and a married man in war-torn Shanghai. It explores themes of love, loss, and the impact of social upheaval.

title: Democracy in America
author: Alexis de Tocqueville
description: A classic work of political thought and observation, *Democracy in America* examines the burgeoning democratic spirit of the United States in the 1830s. Tocqueville analyzes the strengths and weaknesses of American democracy, comparing it to European systems and offering insights into the social, political, and cultural forces shaping the nation.

title: Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus
author: Ludwig Wittgenstein
description: A highly influential work of 20th-century philosophy, the *Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus* attempts to define the relationship between language and reality, and to delineate the limits of what can be said meaningfully. It presents a picture theory of meaning and argues that the limits of our language are the limits of our world.

title: On the Genealogy of Morals
author: Friedrich Nietzsche
description: A critical examination of traditional morality, arguing that moral values are not absolute truths but rather constructs created by specific social groups to serve their interests. Nietzsche explores the origins of concepts like 'good' and 'evil', tracing their development from master morality to slave morality.

title: The Masque of the Red Death
author: Edgar Allan Poe
description: A short story following Prince Prospero's attempt to avoid a deadly plague, known as the Red Death, by secluding himself and his courtiers in a castle. The story explores themes of mortality, isolation, and the futility of trying to escape death.
publisher: The Gift, a volume of tales and poems

title: Love in a F*cked Up World: How to Build Relationships and Raise Hell Together
author: Dean Spade
description: A guide to building strong, resilient relationships and collective liberation, rooted in radical politics and mutual aid. It offers practical tools for navigating difficult conversations, building solidarity, and creating a more just world.

title: De Humani Corporis Fabrica Libri Septem
author: Andreas Vesalius
description: A seminal work of human anatomy, based on direct dissection of human bodies. It revolutionized the study of anatomy and is considered a foundational text in the history of medicine. It corrected many errors from Galen and established a new standard for anatomical illustration.

title: The Book of Mo
author: Penguin Classics
description: A collection of short stories by various authors, curated by Penguin Classics. The stories explore themes of migration, identity, and belonging, focusing on the experiences of people who have moved to or between countries.

title: A History of Western Philosophy
author: Bertrand Russell
description: A comprehensive and influential survey of the history of Western philosophical thought, from the pre-Socratics to the mid-20th century. Russell examines the major philosophers and their ideas, placing them in their historical and social contexts.

title: The Works of Baruch Spinoza
author: Baruch Spinoza
description: A comprehensive collection of the philosophical works of Baruch Spinoza, including his *Ethics*, *Tractatus Theologico-Politicus*, and other treatises. It represents a foundational text in rationalism and modern philosophy.

title: Best-Loved Irish Ballads
author: Emma Byrne
description: A collection of classic and contemporary Irish ballads, celebrating the rich storytelling tradition of Ireland. Includes both well-known and lesser-known songs, with historical and cultural context.

title: Meditations on First Philosophy
author: René Descartes
description: A foundational work of Western philosophy, *Meditations on First Philosophy* presents Descartes' arguments for rationalism and dualism. It explores themes of skepticism, the existence of God, and the distinction between mind and body.

title: Timaeus
author: Plato
description: The Timaeus is a philosophical dialogue written by Plato, believed to be written around 360 BC. It presents a cosmological myth about the creation of the universe, the nature of reality, and the structure of the cosmos. It also discusses the origins of the soul and the human body.

title: Small Things Like These
author: Claire Keegan
description: Set in 1985 Ireland, the novel follows Bill Furlong, a coal merchant, as he uncovers a dark secret about the Magdalene Laundries, institutions where 'fallen women' were confined. It's a poignant exploration of silence, complicity, and the courage to act.

title: Hamlet
author: William Shakespeare
description: Hamlet, Prince of Denmark, grapples with grief, revenge, and moral corruption after the ghost of his father reveals he was murdered by his uncle Claudius, who has taken the throne and married Hamlet's mother. The play explores themes of mortality, justice, and the human condition.

title: To Kill a Mockingbird
author: Harper Lee
description: To Kill a Mockingbird is a novel by Harper Lee published in 1960. It is set in the Depression-era South and deals with themes of racial injustice and the loss of innocence, told through the eyes of Scout Finch.

title: Marx
author: Peter Osborne
description: A critical introduction to the life, thought, and legacy of Karl Marx, examining his key concepts and their relevance to contemporary issues.

title: Anti-Oedipus: Capitalism and Schizophrenia
author: Gilles Deleuze and Félix Guattari
description: A highly influential work of post-structuralist philosophy, *Anti-Oedipus* critiques Freudian psychoanalysis and proposes a radical rethinking of desire, capitalism, and the nature of schizophrenia. It argues that capitalism produces schizophrenia rather than repressing it, and that desire is a productive force rather than a lack.

title: Literature and Science
author: Aldous Huxley
description: A collection of essays by Aldous Huxley exploring the relationship between literature and science, and their impact on human perception and understanding. It delves into topics like perception, communication, and the role of both disciplines in shaping our worldview.

title: Siddhartha
author: Hermann Hesse
description: Siddhartha is a 1922 novel by Hermann Hesse that deals with a spiritual journey of self-discovery. It follows the life of Siddhartha, a young man who leaves his home and family to seek enlightenment.

title: The Oedipus Cycle
author: Sophocles
description: This collection contains the three Theban plays by Sophocles: Oedipus Rex, Oedipus at Colonus, and Antigone. They explore themes of fate, free will, and the consequences of human actions.

title: Statistical Inference
author: George Casella and Roger L. Berger
description: A comprehensive textbook on statistical inference, covering topics such as estimation, hypothesis testing, and Bayesian methods. It is known for its rigorous mathematical treatment and clear explanations.

title: Utopia
author: Thomas More
description: Utopia is a work of political philosophy and social satire by Thomas More, published in 1516. It presents a fictional island society, 'Utopia', and contrasts it with the political and social realities of Europe at the time. The book explores themes of governance, social justice, and the ideal society.

title: The C Programming Language
author: Brian W. Kernighan and Dennis M. Ritchie
description: A classic and highly influential book on the C programming language. It provides a comprehensive introduction to the language and its concepts, serving as a foundational text for many programmers.

title: 沙丘 (Shāqiú)
author: Frank Herbert
description: Dune is a science fiction epic set on the desert planet Arrakis, the only source of the spice melange, a drug that extends life and enhances mental abilities. The novel explores themes of politics, religion, ecology, and the human condition.
publisher: Chilton Books (original English publisher); translated and published in Chinese by various publishers

title: The Life of the Buddha
author: Andrew Rawlinson
description: A biographical account of the life of Siddhartha Gautama, the founder of Buddhism, tracing his journey from prince to enlightened teacher.

title: White Teeth
author: Zadie Smith
description: A multi-ethnic comedy of errors set in London, following the lives of two families—one British, one Bengali—and their interwoven stories over several decades. It explores themes of identity, immigration, and cultural clashes.

title: Learn You a Haskell for Great Good!
author: Miran Lipovača
description: A gentle introduction to the Haskell programming language, aimed at beginners. It uses a humorous and approachable style to teach functional programming concepts.

title: Brave New World
author: Aldous Huxley
description: A dystopian novel set in a futuristic World State where people are genetically engineered and conditioned to fit into a rigid social hierarchy. It explores themes of technology, control, individuality, and happiness.

title: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders
author: American Psychiatric Association
description: The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM) is a publication of the American Psychiatric Association that serves as the primary diagnostic tool for mental health professionals. It provides a common language and standard criteria for classifying mental disorders.

title: Tao Te Ching
author: Lao Tzu
description: The Tao Te Ching (also known as the Daodejing) is a fundamental text of Taoist philosophy, attributed to the Chinese philosopher Lao Tzu. It explores the Tao (the Way), emphasizing living in harmony with the natural order.

title: Three Dialogues Between Hylas and Philonous
author: George Berkeley
description: A philosophical work presenting Berkeley's theory of idealism, arguing that 'to be is to be perceived'. It's a classic text in epistemology and metaphysics.

title: On the Soul
author: Aristotle
description: A foundational work of psychology and philosophy, *On the Soul* explores the nature of life, perception, thought, and the relationship between body and soul. Aristotle examines the different kinds of living beings and their capacities, offering insights into the workings of the mind and the principles of living organisms.

title: Leaves of Grass
author: Walt Whitman
description: Leaves of Grass is a collection of poetry by Walt Whitman, first published in 1855. It is considered a landmark work of American literature, celebrating democracy, nature, and the human spirit. Whitman continually revised and expanded the collection throughout his life.

title: The Little Book of Cocktails
author: Various
description: A comprehensive guide to classic and contemporary cocktails, featuring recipes, techniques, and beautiful photography.

title: White Nights
author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
description: A sentimental short story about a lonely dreamer in 19th-century St. Petersburg who encounters a young woman and experiences a brief, hopeful connection. It explores themes of loneliness, unrequited love, and the power of imagination.
publisher: Various (originally published in a literary collection)

title: Karl Marx: Selected Writings
author: Karl Marx
description: A collection of key writings by Karl Marx, including 'A Contribution to the Critique of Hegel's Philosophy of Right', 'The German Ideology' (with Friedrich Engels), 'The Eighteenth Brumaire of Louis Bonaparte', and 'Critique of the Gotha Programme'. These works explore Marx's theories on historical materialism, class struggle, and the critique of capitalism.

title: Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals
author: Immanuel Kant
description: A foundational text in moral philosophy, *Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals* lays out Kant's ethical theory, focusing on the concept of the categorical imperative and duty-based ethics. It explores the principles of morality and how humans should act based on reason and universal laws.

title: The Autobiography of Malcolm X
author: Malcolm X and Alex Haley
description: A powerful and influential autobiography detailing Malcolm X's early life, conversion to Islam, and his evolving views on race, politics, and religion. It chronicles his journey from a troubled youth to a prominent civil rights activist.

title: Rhetoric
author: Aristotle
description: Aristotle's *Rhetoric* is a foundational work on the art of persuasive speaking and writing. It systematically examines the means of persuasion, including ethos, pathos, and logos, and provides a comprehensive guide to effective communication.

title: How to Relax
author: Thich Nhat Hanh
description: A guide to finding peace and relaxation in everyday life through the practice of mindfulness, based on Buddhist teachings.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
author: Ken Kesey
description: A story set in an Oregon psychiatric hospital, narrated by a new patient, Chief Bromden, about the power struggles between patients and the oppressive Nurse Ratched. It explores themes of freedom, conformity, and the definition of sanity.

title: Ethics
author: Baruch Spinoza
description: Spinoza's *Ethics* is a landmark work of rationalist philosophy, presenting a systematic and rigorous argument for a deterministic worldview and a unique ethical system based on reason and self-preservation. It explores concepts of God, the nature of reality, human freedom, and the path to happiness.

title: Civilization and Its Discontents
author: Sigmund Freud
description: A seminal work in which Freud examines the inherent tensions between the demands of civilization and the individual's instinctual drives. He explores the sources of unhappiness in human culture and the psychological costs of repression.

title: Inequality
author: Harry Frankfurt
description: In this book, Harry Frankfurt explores the concept of inequality, arguing that it is not necessarily a bad thing, and that a certain degree of inequality is inevitable and even desirable in a free society. He examines the moral and political implications of inequality, and offers a nuanced and thought-provoking analysis of this complex issue.

title: The Republic
author: Plato
description: The Republic is Plato's most famous work, and one of the most influential books in the history of Western thought. It explores justice, the ideal state, and the nature of the soul through a series of dialogues between Socrates and other characters.

title: Selected Poems
author: T.S. Eliot
description: A collection of poems by T.S. Eliot, including works from his earlier and later periods. This edition is part of the Faber and Faber 'Poetry Pamphlets' series.

title: Parmenides
author: Plato
description: Parmenides is a philosophical dialogue attributed to the ancient Greek philosopher Plato. It explores the nature of Being, One, and Many, and is considered one of Plato's most challenging and complex works. It features a discussion between Socrates and the Eleatic philosopher Parmenides, and his disciple Zeno.

title: La Philosophie de la Nature
author: Jacques Maritain
description: A philosophical treatise exploring the concept of nature, drawing on Aristotelian and Thomistic thought. Maritain examines the relationship between nature, knowledge, and the supernatural order.

title: A Streetcar Named Desire
author: Tennessee Williams
description: A Streetcar Named Desire is a play by Tennessee Williams that premiered in 1947. It tells the story of Blanche DuBois, a Southern belle who arrives in New Orleans to stay with her sister and brother-in-law, and her subsequent struggles with reality and her own fading beauty.

title: Parmenides
author: Martin Heidegger
description: A detailed and critical examination of the pre-Socratic philosopher Parmenides, exploring his poem 'On Nature' and its implications for Western thought. Heidegger interprets Parmenides' work as a foundational text for understanding Being and Truth.

title: On History
author: Immanuel Kant
description: A foundational work of historical philosophy by Immanuel Kant, exploring the concept of history as a process guided by rational purposes and the pursuit of a universal civil society. It examines the role of natural predispositions in human history and the progression towards a state of peace and justice.

title: State and Revolution
author: Vladimir Lenin
description: A foundational Marxist work outlining Lenin's theory of the state and revolution, arguing for the necessity of a proletarian dictatorship. It analyzes the state as an instrument of class rule and proposes a strategy for overthrowing the bourgeois state and establishing a socialist one.

title: The Civil War in France
author: Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels
description: A historical and political analysis of the Paris Commune of 1871, written by Karl Marx. It defends the Commune and critiques its suppression by the French government, offering insights into Marxist theories of class struggle and revolution.
publisher: Various (originally published as a pamphlet, later compiled into book form)

title: The Complete Kama Sutra
author: Vatsyayana
description: The Kama Sutra is an ancient Indian text widely considered to be the foundational text of *kama* (sensual desire) which is one of the four goals of human life in Hinduism. It is a comprehensive work on human sexual behavior, love, and relationships, but also includes guidance on various aspects of life, including social etiquette, art, and poetry.

title: On the Origin of Species
author: Charles Darwin
description: A foundational work of evolutionary biology, 'On the Origin of Species' introduces the theory of evolution by natural selection. Darwin presents evidence supporting the idea that species evolve over time through a process of 'natural selection', where organisms with advantageous traits are more likely to survive and reproduce.

title: Calculus: Early Transcendentals
author: James Stewart
description: A widely used calculus textbook known for its clear explanations, numerous examples, and applications to real-world problems. It covers single variable calculus, including limits, derivatives, integrals, and applications.

title: National Geographic: The World's Most Beautiful Places
author: National Geographic
description: A collection of stunning photographs showcasing the world's most beautiful and inspiring destinations, curated by National Geographic.
